characters: THE OPENING OF THE SPACESHIP'S HATCH
MARINES SURROUND SPACECRAFT AT THE READY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It soars into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: through whose windows the same light lividly illuminates three space-suited and helmeted ASTRONAUTS  -- afraid and curiously hesitant at the controls. We establish a Dual Date Meter showing the year in terms both of "EARTH TIME" and "SELF-TIME." Both panels read: 3955.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1, (MALE)
dialogues.text: We made it.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2, (MALE)
dialogues.text: So far. But one thing i8 for certain. Whoever wins the war, there'll be no place on Earth for us.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3, (FEMALE)
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2, (MALE)
dialogues.text: (briskly) Probably to our death. But just possibly --

dialogues.speaker: EARTH'S RIM WHITENS TO INCANDESCENCE
dialogues.text: and a soundless explosion sends a column of fire an mushrooming up towards us.

dialogues.speaker: SPACESHIP
dialogues.text: Appalled silence. Through the ship's windows the ASTRONAUTS are watching (and we with them) the nuclear disintegration of Earth. The incandescence almost burns through their space helmets. In awed voices:

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: The fools...they've finally destroyed themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: My God, the earth is no more.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3
dialogues.text: And we've escaped. The spaceship begins to shudder.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: We have, if we survive the shock wave. The shock wave of the huge, megatonic explosion hits the spaceship from below. Chaos and pandemonium inside. We multiply normal air turbulence a thousandfold and are bashed, buffeted, whirled, twirled, lifted a hundred miles and dropped fifty, before slowly flattening out to some semblance of equilibrium on (presumably) a new orbit. The Date  Meter digits under "EARTH TIME" have begun to click and race erratically. ASTRONAUT 2 watches intently.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: The shock must have unbalanced the mechanism. I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he turns to look at another dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across it curves the descending graphline which traces optimum re-entry path. Now the lights begin to trace the spacecraft's actual re-entry path, which sometimes slightly deviates to left or right of the graphline but always approximately follows its course.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: We've been forced out of orbit.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: (looking at panel) We're descending.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3
dialogues.text: But where? The spacecraft is seared with flames and smoke as it plummets through space. The windows fog and blacken. ASTRONAUT feverishly works at controls to no response.

dialogues.speaker: SPACECRAFT, (STOCK)
dialogues.text: The fiery missile descends on our screen.

dialogues.speaker: FLAMES AND SMOKE
dialogues.text: leap at the windows. Descent is rapid, and suddenly through the blackened windows the entry is completed for light can be seen flickering through the charred cracks. SUBJECTIVE P.O.V. We descend rapidly to be swallowed in a cloud bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING across the frozen ASTRONAUTS, we see the Date Meter spin to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are crashing rapidly into the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: F-5 SPLASHDOWN, (STOCK)
dialogues.text: The spacecraft split the water into churning waves. Then all is still.

dialogues.speaker: EARTH
dialogues.text: We are watching it from the P.O.V. of a U.S. Marine helicopter PILOT flying on normal coastal reconnaissance duty; and the coast itself as plane banks to include it) is California. All is peaceful, empty and deserted. Until...PILOT mildly reacts to an object beached on the tideline far below. His prop- blades louden as he goes into a steep, investigatory dive. 7 FROM PILOT'S P.O.V. We ZOOM towards the floating and still-unopened spaceship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he flattens off and reascends:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: (radio-reporting) Tower, this is Red Baron Five. I have an object beached on the tide- line -- uh -- seemingly one of our spacecraft. Coordinates are southeast corner of sector Alpha Charlie. Relay this to appropriate recovery forces. I have enough fuel to orbit for forty- five minutes. Please alert Red Baron Ops and I'll squawk Channel Two for radar fix.

dialogues.speaker: DUTY OFFICER
dialogues.text: (on phone) Rescue, we have Red Baron Five report of possible spacecraft washed ashore in southeast sector Alpha Charlie. Immediately launch two choppers to effect pickup and recovery. Base Radar will vector them to the location.  10 11 12 13 14 He picks up second phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: DUTY OFFICER
dialogues.text: The Colonel, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COLONEL, among friends, is barbecuing a steak on the lawn of his private quarters as the garden phone rings beside him. The roar of the o.s. helicopters passing overhead and the nature of the phone message itself distract him from the steak which, during the brief conversation's course, is burnt to a cinder. As the helicopters recede:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: I didn't even know we had anything up. Okay, I'll call Washington. (seeing burnt steak) Damn!

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE IN WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: 3-star GENERAL BRODY stands against wall map of splashdown area and barks into phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: No serial number? ... Well, it may have been burnt out on re-entry. ... No, neither did I. I'll check with Deputy Director, NASA, and call you back. He cuts the call to initiate a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: disgorging FROGMEN at spacecraft. First helicopter departs.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE AT CAPE KENNEDY
dialogues.text: INTERCUTTING DEPUTY DIRECTOR with BRODY in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY DIRECTOR, (CIVILIAN)
dialogues.text: (patiently) General Brody, I'm telling you... We have no spacecraft up.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (irritably) You're telling me that what never went up can't come down. And I'm telling you it just has. And now I'm going to tell the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Military vehicles, combat Marines, trucks, jeeps, etc. swarm.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE OFFICE
dialogues.text: The PRESIDENT is an articulate, unruffled professional politician with a flair for irony. Into phone:

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Let us hope and pray that you are right, General. But I think we should be alert to a remoter possibility: that the Russians retrieved one of our missing space- ships and remanned it with astronauts who have now accidentally splashed down in our own territorial waters. If they're alive, you may tell Colonel Winthrop at El Palomar to welcome them with caution. Whether they're alive or not, have NASA go over that ship with whatever's the scientific equivalent of a fine tooth comb. And until we know more, I want a full security clampdown on the entire operation. (dryly) You understand me, General. This is not for the networks. being towed ashore by cable attached to truck winch.

dialogues.speaker: FROGMEN,
dialogues.text: beach.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE SPACESHIP
dialogues.text: swimming alongside, shout orders to truck on Its windows still fogged and blackened; the OCCUPANTS still helmeted. We hear 0.S. FROGMEN faintly shouting orders from outside.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: We are being pulled.  19 20 21 22 23 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do you hold onto this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Frogman you are. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: They speak our language. At least they have intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: (urgently) Then at least let us conceal our intelligence from our captors. Our safety may lie in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and lands on beach. COLONEL emerges, with two AIDES, to view:

dialogues.speaker: THE OPENING OF THE SPACESHIP'S HATCH
dialogues.text: Our helmeted ASTRONAUTS emerge, descend; and draw the selves up, line abreast, facing:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Welcome, gentlemen. Then their faces stiffen in aghast astonishment, as we:

dialogues.speaker: THE ASTRONAUTS UNHELMETED
dialogues.text: They are all chimpanzees. One of them (MILO) is a character new to our series. The other two are CORNELIUS and is wife ZIRA. Over their heads we SUPER:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE AND CREDITS
dialogues.text: which continue over a:

dialogues.speaker: A. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Frozen shot of the three apes.

dialogues.speaker: B. CREDIT
dialogues.text: A shot of the Colonel and two aides. Camera ZOOMS into head shot of Colonel. C. CREDIT: RODDY McDOWALL Close shot of Cornelius. Pull back to Med. shot. He looks off.

dialogues.speaker: D. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Camera pans to Zira.

dialogues.speaker: E. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Full shot - beach action. Colonel and two aides run towards jeep.

dialogues.speaker: F. CREDIT NATALIE TRUNDY
dialogues.text: Colonel in f£.g. reaches for phone in jeep. Two aides in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: G. CREDIT
dialogues.text: General Brody reacting to news on telephone (freeze frame).

dialogues.speaker: H. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Deputy Director, NASA, reacting to news (freeze frame).

dialogues.speaker: I. CREDIT
dialogues.text: President of the U.S. reacting to the news (freeze frame) . Jd. CREDIT: RICARDO MONTALBAN AS ARMANDO Full shot - Ops Room receiving news on teletype.

dialogues.speaker: K. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Tighter shot - Ops Room - activity on phone.

dialogues.speaker: L. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Full shot - security gate. Trucks and ambulance entering air base. M. CREDIT: ART DIRECTION, ETC. Security gates being closed Zooming into off- limits sign.

dialogues.speaker: N. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Full shot - trucks and ambulance arriving at air base depot. oO. CREDIT: UNIT MANAGER, ETC. Ambulance being opened to admit Ape-onauts.  Py CREDIT: PANAVISION, ETC. by soldiers to guardhouse (director's note: possible two shot).

dialogues.speaker: Q. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Low-bed truck carrying spacecraft.

dialogues.speaker: R. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Tighter shot on moving truck carrying spacecraft. Ss. CREDIT: PRODUCED BY Jeep arriving at air base depot. Aide to Colonel enters building.

dialogues.speaker: T. CREDIT
dialogues.text: Colonel and Aide emerge from building heading towards guardhouse. MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who is carrying a large paperbag, as they walk past Headquarters Buildings.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Did you call the Zoo?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We're in luck. The sick bay's almost empty except for a mauled fox cub, a deer with pneumonia, and a depressed gorilla. The Apes will be hidden from the public. They'll be quarantined. If they want medical attention, it's available on the spot. And the experts can start giving them the once-over first thing in the morning. General Brody's very pleased.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Me, too. Can't have a lot of monkeys making messes in the Guardhouse. Have we fed them? Like raw steak or something?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: The Zoo tells me that chimpanzees, like all apes, are vegetarian, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: (indicating paper bag) They suggested oranges.  They have reached:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: whose door is unlocked by an obviously shaken MARINE M.P.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: What's the matter? MARINE M.P. helplessly ushers them into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its rear section (behind bars) is furnished with austere but serviceable beds, chairs, tables and a washing sink with plates and cutlery in rack above. On the floor: a capacious rawhide valise, from which ZIRA (gloved and shod) has extracted a robe into which she is changing. Her discarded space suit lies at her feet. MILO and CORNELIUS have already changed. Their space suits are hanging neatly from wall hooks. At COLONEL'S entry, MILO and CORNELIUS rise courteously to their feet, while ZIRA struggles hastily into her robe. From the threshold:

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (automatically) Excuse me. I didn't mean to disturb.... (aghast to Aide) What am I saying?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: They're...pretending to dress.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: What d'you mean, pretending? They are dressing. Where'd they get those clothes? MARINE M.P. (indicating valise) They brought them with them, sir. (gulping) In a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Suit....? (with an effort; to Aide) Greg, give them their oranges. AIDE advances cautiously with paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HOLD COLONEL and MARINE M.P. talking in f.g., while AIDE proffers oranges (which the TRIO gracefully accepts) in b.g. ZIRA, holding her orange, has gone straight to the sink rack, from which she takes three plates, three knives and three forks.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (not noticing; to Marine M.P.) Arrange prisoner escort for 16:30 hours... ZIRA distributes plates and cutlery to MILO and CORNELIUS. To AIDE's astonishment, the APES draw up chairs and sit round the table.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (not noticing; to Aide) We're sending them to the Zoo Infirmary. The APES start meticulously quartering their oranges on their plates with their knives.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (still to Aide) They'll have company. There's a gorilla in the next cage. ZIRA, overhearing this, reacts violently; rises, picks up her plate and hurls it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (looking round at last) Now why the hell did it do that? The full implications of the plates and the knives only strike him as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We START on CLOSE SHOT of the deer with pneumonia, cradled under ultraviolet lamps which (as we PULL BACK) prove to be the huge, clinically furnished room's only light source -- for the sick animals must get their rest. We PAN past a recumbent camel and the mauled fox cub, into whose small sleeping body the rubber tube of a suspended flask is intravenously dripping plasma; and END on a white-coated KEEPER (with flashlamp) inspecting our APE TRIO, now installed in one of two  large, contiguous cages at the dim room's center: straw for them to lie on; a bowl of water for drinking; and a generous supply of oranges and bananas, one of which he cautiously proffers to ZIRA through the bars, while playfully patting her head. ZIRA reacts the banana and slaps his face. Taken aback but still amicably:

dialogues.speaker: KEEPER
dialogues.text: Have it your own way, mate. Clang! He locks them in and exits. When the light from his flashlamp has faded to near-darkness, we hear an outer door more distantly locked.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (outraged whisper to Cornelius) I'm not his mate. I'm yours.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira, please control yourself. I think they're trying to be kind.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: This cage stinks of gorilla. She sits down disconsolately on the straw. Instantly CORNELIUS sits by her and takes her hand. In undertones:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Cornelius -- where are we? What's happened? CORNELIUS helplessly shrugs. From the shadows, very softly:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I know where we are. I know what has happened. ZIRA and CORNELIUS stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: In some fashion -- and I lack the intellect to know precisely how -- we have traveled from Earth's future into Earth's past.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: But we saw Earth destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And Earth will be destroyed -- just as we saw it. Only, since fleeing it, we have passed through  a....backward disturbance in time -- did you notice the Date Meter clicking down after the shock wave hit our ship? -- and we have returned to Earth almost two thousand years before its destruction. (solemnly) That is another reason for keeping silence. Our human captors would not be edified to know that, one day, their world will crack like an egg and fry to a cinder, because of an Ape war of aggression. His low tones have become just emphatic enough to disturb:

dialogues.speaker: GORILLA IN NEXT CAGE
dialogues.text: It shifts, grunts and whimpers uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The TRIO reacts. We CLOSE to:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Apes, at this instant in time, cannot yet talk. For the moment, we should follow their example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear occasional call of a tropical early bird, and CLOSE to two human early birds: LEWIS DIXON, a young animal psychiatrist, and his pretty (female) research assistant, STEVIE. As they walk: He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (feeling in pocket) The driver brought e report from the Air Base. (scanning it) The usual imitatory behavior ... mimicking salutes ... hand-shaking ... sitting on chairs ... eating off plates with knives ... but--

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What, Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: There was a sort of carpetbag in the ship.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: With food?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: No -- clothes. Stevie, they changed into them.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. But his reaction says it is true. We have reached the Infirmary's main (open) door which is guarded by two SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What are they doing here?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Security. (undertone) Join the Marines and see the Zoo ... Passing between the SOLDIERS, they enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don white smocks (marked with their own names) hanging from wall hooks; walk past the sick deer and the fox under treatment in small box-cages against the wall; and enter:

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: In one half of the cage sleeps the depressed GORILLA; in the other half, very much awake, sit CORNELIUS and ZIRA staring at the Intelligence Test apparatus. Outside the cage stands KEEPER.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Hi, Dr. Dixon..... Dr. Branton. Our APES survey them stonily.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (fingering bruise on cheek)  The female's a bit uppity, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll be careful. We'll start with the Wisconsin Multiphasic. STEVIE opens the cage.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Go easy, Stevie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: They look pretty docile.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Yes, but don't take any chances. The Wisconsin Multiphasic is a screen which can be lowered and raised (like a window shade) between the Investigator on one side and the Subject on the other. ZIRA winks knowledgeably at CORNELIUS. MILO gestures her into more discreet behavior. KEEPER sets up apparatus during:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (to Stevie) Unless the spacecraft was remotely controlled, they must have been conditioned to press at least some of the right buttons. They can't be morons. (to Keeper) The female first, Arthur. And set up Tic-Tac-Toe. To everyone's surprise and KEEPER's relief, ZIRA promptly squats down on her side of the raised screen. The hyper-cautious MILO disapprovingly shakes his head. LEWIS raises screen and displays a single red cube for three seconds before lowering screen to mask ZIRA's view. When he raises it again, he is simultaneously displaying a blue pyramid, a green cone, a yellow sphere, a blue cube, a red octahedron and the red cube. ZIRA instantly selects the red cube, which she offers courteously back to LEWIS. LEWIS gives an astonished whistle. STEVIE, too, reacts in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: She seems to be pretty smart. All right -- let's make it difficult. He lowers the screen, and readies an assortment of five colored blocks, then raises the screen only for a second, then lowers it. He now adds additional blocks to make it an even dozen, and breaks up the pattern of  five previously seen by ZIRA. Now, almost smugly, he raises the screen, but any superiority he may have felt is quickly erased as ZIRA swiftly selects the original five blocks. LEWIS is dumbfounded, STEVIE drops her notebook and the KEEPER stares in utter disbelief. Now, LEWIS pulls the drawer out from the table, and we see that slots for all twelve blocks have been carved in the bottom. No slouch ZIRA. She deftly and swiftly fits all twelve blocks into their proper niches. Whereat she rises to her feet, clasps hands over her head like a boxer acknowledging victory. CORNELIUS responds with mirth, but MILO shakes his head. LEWIS has risen at this interplay between the apes and now questions the KEEPER quietly.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: They haven't eaten this morning?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Not a bite....just as you ordered.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Good. We'll go for the banana... Scattered about the cage are a number of oddly constructed wooden boxes, all gaily painted. STEVIE now adds several more, as ARTHUR tugs on a rope pulley to lower a banana from the top of the cage. This is a test unfamiliar to ZIRA, who responds to its challenge. She speculatively eyes the banana; then stoops to prowl among the boxes, which she carefully examines without touching them. Then she straightens... and thinks. The tension is insupportable. Suddenly ZIRA, moving into action, interlocks all the boxes so that they form a somewhat eccentric staircase leading to the banana. Having done so, she ascends the "stairs," sits on the top, and stares smugly at the banana, now only inches from her nose.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Why doesn't she take it?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Because I loathe and detest bananas.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira! As though in a slow nightmare, STEVIE sags and faints. Somehow, LEWIS catches her and lowers her to the cage floor. Somehow, KEEPER sluices water from the drinking bowl over her upturned race. As she recovers:  34 35

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (sweating) Help me get her away. I'll come back. Jointly supporting STEVIE, they leave the cage, which KEEPER locks.

dialogues.speaker: APE TRIO
dialogues.text: We STAY with:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Zira, are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Dr. Milo, please don't call my wife mad.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: (evenly) I did not call her mad. I merely asked her if she was. And I repeat the question. (to Zira) Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I hate deceit.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: There is a time for truth and a time, not for lies, but for silence. Until we know who i8 our friend and who our enemy--

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: And how in the name of God are we to know that, unless we communicate? We can speak. So I spoke.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: We can also listen

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: To a lot of psychiatric small talk --

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And we can watch ...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: A display of primitive apparatus --

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (kicking the apparatus) Primitive? Its prehistoric. It  36

dialogues.speaker: TO
dialogues.text: couldn't test the intelligence of a newt. She kicks the apparatus again, and it collapses. The GORILLA in the next cage gives a disturbed grunt.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira, calm yourself --

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I am calm. She knocks another piece of apparatus endways. Now even MILO's self-control snaps. He stalks to the side bars and (with eyes screwed shut in frustration) briefly but fiercely shakes them before spinning round, with back pressed against the bars, to glare at his two tormentors. We SHOOT AT AND PAST HIM into the next cage where the GORILLA now shambles to its feet and slowly advances from b.g., during:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Stop arguing. It's too late for that. His body masking the GORILLA's crouched and stealthy approach from them -- but not from us.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Use your heads and start thinking. Now that they know we can speak, how much shall we tell them? ow--

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (screaming) Milo-o-o! Through the bars two hairy hands converge on MILO's throat and strangle him to death. The roaring of the GORILLA, the throttled cries of MILO and ZIRA's screams combine to launch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of alarmed birds and beasts as panic briefly infects the Zoo. E.g., a sleeping owl opens huge eyes; cranes cry; mallards take off from pool; seals cough; apes gibber; tigers snarl; lions roar, and elephants trumpet. We might (instead of separating each cry overlay sound cumulatively so that each new noise is added to its predecessors, as we build visually and aurally to a massive and bestial crescendo before:

dialogues.speaker: THE CAGE
dialogues.text: The "panic" is over. Outside, STEVIE (shaken but recovered) confers with LEWIS. As KEEPERS 1 and 2 lift a blanketed stretcher and carry MILO's body out of shot:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: We shall want a full autopsy ...

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: With particular emphasis on the cranial and oral areas.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Keep him in cold storage till the reports in. Then send him to Taxidermy. (wryly) He's a museum piece. A low moan turns their heads toward the cage's interior. ZIRA sits crouched in a corner, her head in her hands and rocking from side to side. CORNELIUS is comforting her.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (to Stevie) I'd better do this alone. She nods and stays outside the cage, which LEWIS enters. He looks compassionately at the two huddled APES, the straw, the orange peel, the bananas, the abandoned Intelligence Test apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (gently) We mean you no harm. Silence and stillness.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Do you understand? We mean you no harm. Slowly and bitterly, ZIRA points an ironic and accusing finger at the next cage, where an anesthetized and chained GORILLA slumps in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: But he isn't us. He's your own kind.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (angrily on her feet in a flash) He's a gorilla.  As CORNELIUS soothes her:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I mean he's of your race. He's an Ape. Look. You don't have to be afraid. We've put him in chains and under sedation. Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I should. I've been doing it half my life to Humans.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (dumb founded) Humans?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (as though this explained everything) I'm a psychiatrist. A second shock. LEWIS covers dazed eyes with his hand and, after a struggle, regains his self-control.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: So am I. And I mean you no harm.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (at last) We know that. LEWIS, over one hurdle, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Do you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: My name is Cornelius. And this is Zira -- my wife.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: My name is Lewis -- Lewis Dixon He diffidently extends a hand, CORNELIUS takes it. ZIRA doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Nobody's going to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Believe what?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: That primitive apes can talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Primitive?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (quick smile) I mean that in our ‘primitive’ civilization, apes just don't talk. I mean I think it's important that, when our ‘primitive’ security precautions are lifted, the first time you say something in public you should talk to what we 'primitively' call the Right People. ZIRA gives him a long, searching look ... and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: May I say something personal?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (smiling back) Please

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I like you. LEWIS look gratefully from her to:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: I did from the beginning. TO BE CONTINUED...
